awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Monolithic Phononic Crystals and Programmable Surface Acoustic Wave Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
The last few decades, a number of major technological breakthroughs are mainly enabled by our ability to control two elementary particles: electrons and photons. Phonon is another important elementary particle that is responsible from heat and sound transfer. However, there are only limited studies focused on exploiting phonons for our needs. Harvesting phonons, specifically surface acoustic waves, could lead to new practical microfluidic devices with novel properties. Acoustic phonons can exert strong radiation forces to bioparticles (viruses, bacteria and cell) and manipulate them with high precision and efficiency. This proposal offers using phononic crystals to achieve this. Incorporation of such phononic crystals with microfluidics provides an unprecedented level of control on surface acoustic waves in microfluidic system. This capability can potentially lead to monolithic, ultra-compact, versatile and programmable microfluidic devices. Fusing of phononics and microfluidics could open door to a new world of lab-on-chip biomedical technologies and impact everyday life in previously unthinkable ways, in a similar fashion to how electrons and photons did so far. The educational component of this program is expected to provide UCSC undergraduate and graduate students with interdisciplinary training in physics, electrical engineering and biological sciences. Outcomes of the research will be integrated in a graduate student curriculum and results will be disseminated to broader audience by presentations to middle school Girls through 'Girls in Engineering Program' and to underrepresented minorities  through 'Multicultural Engineering Program'
  
The objective of this research proposal is to explore the feasibility of developing microfluidic devices with new functionalities using phononic crystals on silicon substrates. Phononic crystals offer potentially unlimited ways of tailoring acoustic waves. However, to date, they have not been used in acousto-microfluidic applications, other than few simple applications related to mixing and guiding of microdroplets resting on a solid substrate in open air. Full integration of continuous flow microfluidics and phononic crystals has yet to be demonstrated. This project aims to demonstrate practical, facile utilization of phononic crystals in acoustofluidics by making use of the concepts such as band gap formation and evanescent modes of defect states. In this one-year proposal, two basic design concepts will be explored: (i) phononic crystal reflectors, and (ii) phononic crystal waveguide structures. These two structures offer a complete set of basic building blocks to achieve more complex phononic crystal microfluidics with enhanced capabilities (see motivation section below). This one-year project has four specific goals:  (1)To design phononic crystal devices with theoretical modeling and finite element  simulations. (2)To fabricate of phononic crystal devices and integrate them with interdigital transducers on a silicon substrate. (3)To characterize surface acoustic wave behavior of the integrated structures. (4)To integrate microfluidics with phononic crystals and interdigital transducers to achieve size based micro-particle separation and micro-particle guiding. The proposed research program involves numerical design of monolithic acoustofluidic systems in which particle manipulation is taken care of by phononic crystals through techniques, such as finite-element method. The devices are fabricated using well-established microfabrication techniques such as photolithography, metal deposition, soft lithography and deep reactive ion etching. In this proposal, microfuidic testing will be limited to fluorescent silica particles for rapid device development purposes.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past century, our ability to manipulate elementary particles such as electrons and photons in artificially structured crystals (heterostructure semiconductors, photonics crystals)  have led to major technological advancements in information, biomedical and energy technologies. Another elementary particle phonon - associated to the collective mechanical oscillations in periodic structures- plays a crucially important role in many physical characteristics of materials. There is significant interest in mastering phononic behavior in artificially created crystals (meta-materials) for practical purposes. Similar to electronic and photonic revolution, our ability to precisely control mechanical oscillations could lead to new technologies transforming our society and everyday lives. However, the lack of understanding how to control phonons at will and the difficulty of manufacturing phononic materials has been a major bottleneck so far. 

This project focuses on development of acoustofluidic technologies that utilize monolithic phononic crystals (PnCs) consisting of precisely designed and fabricated structures with alternating elastic moduli. Phonons are responsible for a wide range physical phenomena spanning from atomic scale oscillations to seismic waves with thousands of kilometer wavelengths. Here, we are interested in phononic vibrations on the order of micrometer scale corresponding to surface acoustic waves. Acoustic phonons at these frequencies (10 MHz -50 MHz) are suitable for applications related to size based manipulation and sorting of micrometer scale bioparticles (such as cells and bacteria). Advancements in this field could lead to development of compact and cost-efficient lab-on-chip platforms for point-of-care disease diagnostics and high-throughput biomedical research instruments. To date, there were very few and simple demonstrations of PnCs related to mixing and guiding of microdroplets resting on a solid substrate in open air. Integration of continuous flow microfluidics and PnCs for practical purposes was yet to be demonstrated. To the best of our knowledge, we successfully demonstrated the first practical, facile utilization of phononic crystals for continuous flow microfluidics during this project. To achieve our goals, we first developed robust design and testing cycles incorporating finite element acoustofluidic simulation tools and novel fabrication techniques. A critical bottleneck was difficulty of fabricating phononic crystals with high-reliability. To do this, we developed a custom made piezoelectric domain control tool allowing us to fabricate monolithically integrated phononic crystals with high-yield and high-throughput. This capability allowed us to fabricate and test a number of oue novel PnC acoustofluidic device designs in-house with a rapid turn-around time. In our experiments, we demonstrated complete band-gap formation using surface phonon-polaritons and PnC reflectors leading to total phase reversal and phase-coherent reflection of phonons. This allowed us to use spectral degree of freedom of PnCs to create cascaded acoutofluidic devices on a single substrate. Furthermore, we discovered a novel acousto-microfluidic phenomenon – Acoustic Drifting Effect (ADE), enabling us to overcome mass transport limitations in microfluidic channels. ADE offers a paradigm shift in acoustofluidics field by allowing high efficiency isolation of micrometer scale bioparticles such as rare cells. To the best of our knowledge, ADE based enhanced isolation of bioparticles is first of its kind and entirely different from previous acoustophoretic microfluidic devices and field flow fractionation technologies. In addition to the knowhow generated during this project, Four undergraduate students and two graduate students are trained during the project period. All of the undergraduate students worked in this project are applied and admitted to graduate schools. One of students has already completed her MSc thesis on PnCs in Yanik Group.

  • (a-c) PnC based linear defect waveguides for surface acoustic waves (SAWs) are illustrated. Microparticles with different sizes flow inside a microfluidic channel. (d) A gradient-index PnC that can focus different frequency SAWs to different focal points for particle sorting is shown.
